His cocks do win the battle still of mine,
When it is all to nought; and his quails ever
Beat mine, inhoop’d, at odds. I will to Egypt;
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
I’ th’ East my pleasure lies.
O, come, Ventidius,
You must to Parthia. Your commission’s ready;
Follow me, and receive’t.

scene.scenedescription: Lepidus bids farewell to Maecenas and Agrippa.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Trouble yourselves no further; pray you hasten
Your generals after.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Sir, Mark Antony
Will e’en but kiss Octavia, and we’ll follow.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Till I shall see you in your soldier’s dress,
Which will become you both, farewell.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: We shall,
As I conceive the journey, be at the Mount
Before you, Lepidus.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Your way is shorter,
My purposes do draw me much about.
You’ll win two days upon me.

speech.speaker: BOTH. MAEC. AND AGR.
speech.line: Sir, good success!

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Farewell.

scene.scenepersonae: (Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, Alexas, Mardian the Eunuch, Egyptian Messenger)
scene.scenedescription: Cleopatra is lazing about. A terrified messenger informs her that Antony has married Octavia. Furious, she strikes him and threatens to kill him, but he runs away. She apologizes and sends him to gather as much information on Octavia as he can.
scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Give me some music; music, moody food
Of us that trade in love.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: The music, ho!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Let it alone, let’s to billards. Come, Charmian.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: My arm is sore, best play with Mardian.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: As well a woman with an eunuch play’d
As with a woman. Come, You’ll play with me, sir?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: As well as I can, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: And when good will is show’d, though’t come too short,
The actor may plead pardon. I’ll none now.
Give me mine angle, we’ll to th’ river; there,
My music playing far off, I will betray
Tawny-finn’d fishes; my bended hook shall pierce
Their slimy jaws; and as I draw them up,
I’ll think them every one an Antony,
And say, “Ah, ha! Y’ are caught.”

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: ’Twas merry when
You wager’d on your angling; when your diver
Did hang a salt-fish on his hook, which he
With fervency drew up.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: That time? O times!
I laugh’d him out of patience; and that night
I laugh’d him into patience; and next morn,
Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed;
Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst
I wore his sword Philippan.
O, from Italy!
Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears,
That long time have been barren.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Madam, madam—

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Antonio’s dead! If thou say so, villain,
Thou kill’st thy mistress; but well and free,
If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here
My bluest veins to kiss—a hand that kings
Have lipp’d, and trembled kissing.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: First, madam, he is well.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Why, there’s more gold.
But, sirrah, mark, we use
To say the dead are well. Bring it to that,
The gold I give thee will I melt and pour
Down thy ill-uttering throat.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Good madam, hear me.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Well, go to, I will.
But there’s no goodness in thy face, if Antony
Be free and healthful—so tart a favor
To trumpet such good tidings! If not well,
Thou shouldst come like a Fury crown’d with snakes,
Not like a formal man.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Will’t please you hear me?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak’st;
Yet if thou say Antony lives, ’tis well,
Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him,
I’ll set thee in a shower of gold, and hail
Rich pearls upon thee.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Madam, he’s well.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Well said.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: And friends with Caesar.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Th’ art an honest man.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Make thee a fortune from me.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: But yet, madam—

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I do not like “but yet,” it does allay
The good precedence; fie upon ’but yet’!
“But yet” is as a jailer to bring forth
Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend,
Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear,
The good and bad together: he’s friends with Caesar,
In state of health thou say’st, and thou say’st free.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Free, madam, no; I made no such report.
He’s bound unto Octavia.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: For what good turn?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: For the best turn i’ th’ bed.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I am pale, Charmian.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Madam, he’s married to Octavia.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Good madam, patience.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What say you?
Hence,
Horrible villain, or I’ll spurn thine eyes
Like balls before me; I’ll unhair thy head,
speech.stagedir: She hales him up and down.
speech.line: Thou shalt be whipt with wire, and stew’d in brine,
Smarting in ling’ring pickle.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Gracious madam,
I that do bring the news made not the match.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Say ’tis not so, a province I will give thee,
And make thy fortunes proud; the blow thou hadst
Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage,
And I will boot thee with what gift beside
Thy modesty can beg.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: He’s married, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Rogue, thou hast liv’d too long.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Nay then I’ll run.
What mean you, madam? I have made no fault.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself,
The man is innocent.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Some innocents scape not the thunderbolt.
Melt Egypt into Nile! And kindly creatures
Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again,
Though I am mad, I will not bite him. Call!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: He is afeard to come.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I will not hurt him.
These hands do lack nobility that they strike
A meaner than myself, since I myself
Have given myself the cause. Come hither, sir.
Though it be honest, it is never good
To bring bad news. Give to a gracious message
An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell
Themselves when they be felt.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: I have done my duty.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worser than I do,
If thou again say yes.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: He’s married, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: The gods confound thee, dost thou hold there still?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Should I lie, madam?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O, I would thou didst;
So half my Egypt were submerg’d and made
A cestern for scal’d snakes! Go get thee hence!
Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me
Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: I crave your Highness’ pardon.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: He is married?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Take no offense that I would not offend you;
To punish me for what you make me do
Seems much unequal. He’s married to Octavia.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O, that his fault should make a knave of thee,
That art not what th’ art sure of. Get thee hence;
The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too dear for me. Lie they upon thy hand,
And be undone by ’em!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Good your Highness, patience.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: In praising Antony I have disprais’d Caesar.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Many times, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I am paid for’t now.
Lead me from hence;
I faint, O Iras, Charmian! ’Tis no matter.
Go to the fellow, good Alexas, bid him
Report the feature of Octavia, her years,
Her inclination; let him not leave out
The color of her hair. Bring me word quickly.
Let him forever go—let him not, Charmian—
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
The other way’s a Mars.
Bid you Alexas
Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me, Charmian,
But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.

scene.scenepersonae: (Pompey, Menas, Caesar, Lepidus, Antony, Enobarbus, Maecenas, Agrippa, Soldiers)
scene.scenedescription: Pompey and the Triumvirs hold a parley. Pompey is given land and induced to return peacefully to Sicily. They agree to feast together to celebrate. Enobarbus prophesizes that Antony will abandon Octavia to return to Cleopatra, which is sure to cause trouble.
scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter Pompey, Menas at one door, with Drum and Trumpet: at another, Caesar, Lepidus, Antony, Enobarbus, Maecenas, Agrippa, with Soldiers marching.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Your hostages I have, so have you mine;
And we shall talk before we fight.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Most meet
That first we come to words, and therefore have we
Our written purposes before us sent,
Which if thou hast considered, let us know
If ’twill tie up thy discontented sword,
And carry back to Sicily much tall youth
That else must perish here.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: To you all three,
The senators alone of this great world,
Chief factors for the gods: I do not know
Wherefore my father should revengers want,
Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar,
Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted,
There saw you laboring for him. What was’t
That mov’d pale Cassius to conspire? And what
Made all-honor’d, honest, Roman Brutus,
With the arm’d rest, courtiers of beauteous freedom,
To drench the Capitol, but that they would
Have one man but a man? And that is it
Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden
The anger’d ocean foams, with which I meant
To scourge th’ ingratitude that despiteful Rome
Cast on my noble father.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Take your time.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails;
We’ll speak with thee at sea. At land, thou know’st
How much we do o’er-count thee.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: At land indeed
Thou dost o’er-count me of my father’s house;
But since the cuckoo builds not for himself,
Remain in’t as thou mayst.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Be pleas’d to tell us
(For this is from the present) how you take
The offers we have sent you.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: There’s the point.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Which do not be entreated to, but weigh
What it is worth embrac’d.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: And what may follow,
To try a larger fortune.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: You have made me offer
Of Sicily, Sardinia; and I must
Rid all the sea of pirates; then, to send
Measures of wheat to Rome. This ’greed upon,
To part with unhack’d edges and bear back
Our targes undinted.

speech.speaker: CAES. ANT. LEP.
speech.line: That’s our offer.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Know then
I came before you here a man prepar’d
To take this offer; but Mark Antony
Put me to some impatience. Though I lose
The praise of it by telling, you must know,
When Caesar and your brother were at blows,
Your mother came to Sicily and did find
Her welcome friendly.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I have heard it, Pompey,
And am well studied for a liberal thanks,
Which I do owe you.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Let me have your hand.
I did not think, sir, to have met you here.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: The beds i’ th’ East are soft, and thanks to you,
That call’d me timelier than my purpose hither;
For I have gain’d by’t.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Since I saw you last,
There’s a change upon you.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Well, I know not
What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face,
But in my bosom shall she never come,
To make my heart her vassal.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Well met here.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: I hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed.
I crave our composition may be written
And seal’d between us.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: That’s the next to do.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: We’ll feast each other ere we part, and let’s
Draw lots who shall begin.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: That will I, Pompey.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: No, Antony, take the lot; but first
Or last, your fine Egyptian cookery
Shall have the fame. I have heard that Julius Caesar
Grew fat with feasting there.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: You have heard much.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: I have fair meanings, sir.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: And fair words to them.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Then so much have I heard;
And I have heard, Apollodorus carried—

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: No more of that; he did so.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: What, I pray you?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: A certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: I know thee now: how far’st thou, soldier?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Well,
And well am like to do, for I perceive
Four feasts are toward.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Let me shake thy hand,
I never hated thee. I have seen thee fight,
When I have envied thy behavior.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Sir,
I never lov’d you much, but I ha’ prais’d ye
When you have well deserv’d ten times as much
As I have said you did.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Enjoy thy plainness,
It nothing ill becomes thee.
Aboard my galley I invite you all.
Will you lead, lords?

speech.speaker: CAES. ANT. LEP.
speech.line: Show ’s the way, sir.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Come.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Thy father, Pompey, would ne’er have made this treaty.—You and I have known, sir.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: At sea, I think.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: We have, sir.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: You have done well by water.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: And you by land.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: I will praise any man that will praise me, though it cannot be denied what I have done by land.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Nor what I have done by water.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you have been a great thief by sea.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: And you by land.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: There I deny my land service. But give me your hand, Menas; if our eyes had authority, here they might take two thieves kissing.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: All men’s faces are true, whatsome’er their hands are.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: But there is never a fair woman has a true face.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: >No slander, they steal hearts.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: We came hither to fight with you.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: For my part, I am sorry it is turn’d to a drinking. Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: If he do, sure he cannot weep’t back again.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Y’ have said, sir. We look’d not for Mark Antony here. Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Caesar’s sister is call’d Octavia.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: True, sir, she was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Pray ye, sir?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: ’Tis true.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Then is Caesar and he forever knit together.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not prophesy so.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: I think so too. But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity. Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Who would not have his wife so?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Not he that himself is not so; which is Mark Antony. He will to his Egyptian dish again. Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and (as I said before) that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance. Antony will use his affection where it is; he married but his occasion here.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard? I have a health for you.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: I shall take it, sir; we have us’d our throats in Egypt.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Come, let’s away.

scene.scenelocation: On board Pompey’s galley, off Misenum.
scene.scenepersonae: (Pompey’s First Servant, Pompey’s Second Servant, Caesar, Antony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Maecenas, Enobarbus, Menas, Captains)
scene.scenedescription: The greatest rulers in the world grow progressively drunker as they drink to the health of their peace pact. Menas suggests to Pompey that they take the opportunity to assassinate the triumvirate, but Pompey refuses.
scene.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a banquet.

speech.speaker: POM. 1. SERV.
speech.line: Here they’ll be, man. Some o’ their plants are ill rooted already, the least wind i’ th’ world will blow them down.

speech.speaker: POM. 2. SERV.
speech.line: Lepidus is high-color’d.

speech.speaker: POM. 1. SERV.
speech.line: They have made him drink alms-drink.

speech.speaker: POM. 2. SERV.
speech.line: As they pinch one another by the disposition, he cries out, “No more”; reconciles them to his entreaty, and himself to th’ drink.

speech.speaker: POM. 1. SERV.
speech.line: But it raises the greater war between him and his discretion.

speech.speaker: POM. 2. SERV.
speech.line: Why, this it is to have a name in great men’s fellowship. I had as live have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.

speech.speaker: POM. 1. SERV.
speech.line: To be call’d into a huge sphere, and not to be seen to move in’t, are the holes where eyes should be, which pitifully disaster the cheeks.

scene.stagedir: A sennet sounded. Enter Caesar, Antony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Maecenas, Enobarbus, Menas, with other Captains.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o’ th’ Nile
By certain scales i’ th’ pyramid; they know,
By th’ height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth
Or foison follow. The higher Nilus swells,
The more it promises; as it ebbs, the seedsman
Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain,
And shortly comes to harvest.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Y’ have strange serpents there?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Ay, Lepidus.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun. So is your crocodile.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: They are so.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Sit—and some wine! A health to Lepidus!

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: I am not so well as I should be; but I’ll ne’er out.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Not till you have slept; I fear me You’ll be in till then.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Nay certainly, I have heard the Ptolomies’ pyramises are very goodly things; without contradiction, I have heard that.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Pompey, a word.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Say in mine ear, what is’t.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee, captain,
And hear me speak a word.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Forbear me till anon.—
This wine for Lepidus!

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: What manner o’ thing is your crocodile?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: It is shap’d, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it hath breadth. It is just so high as it is, and moves with it own organs. It lives by that which nourisheth it, and the elements once out of it, it transmigrates.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: What color is it of?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Of it own color too.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: ’Tis a strange serpent.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: ’Tis so, and the tears of it are wet.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Will this description satisfy him?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: With the health that Pompey gives him, else he is a very epicure.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that? Away!
Do as I bid you.—Where’s this cup I call’d for?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear me,
Rise from thy stool.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: I think th’ art mad. The matter?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Thou hast serv’d me with much faith; what’s else to say?—
Be jolly, lords.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: These quicksands, Lepidus,
Keep off them, for you sink.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Wilt thou be lord of all the world?

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: What say’st thou?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That’s twice.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: How should that be?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: But entertain it,
And though thou think me poor, I am the man
Will give thee all the world.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Hast thou drunk well?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.
Thou art, if thou dar’st be, the earthly Jove.
What e’er the ocean pales, or sky inclips,
Is thine, if thou wilt ha’t.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Show me which way.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: These three world-sharers, these competitors,
Are in thy vessel. Let me cut the cable,
And when we are put off, fall to their throats:
All there is thine.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Ah, this thou shouldst have done,
And not have spoke on’t! In me ’tis villainy,
In thee’t had been good service. Thou must know,
’Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor;
Mine honor, it. Repent that e’er thy tongue
Hath so betray’d thine act. Being done unknown,
I should have found it afterwards well done,
But must condemn it now. Desist, and drink.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: For this,
I’ll never follow thy pall’d fortunes more.
Who seeks, and will not take when once ’tis offer’d,
Shall never find it more.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: This health to Lepidus!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Bear him ashore. I’ll pledge it for him, Pompey.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Here’s to thee, Menas!

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Enobarbus, welcome!

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Fill till the cup be hid.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: There’s a strong fellow, Menas.

scene.stagedir: Pointing to the Attendant who carries off Lepidus.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Why?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: ’A bears the third part of the world, man; seest not?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: The third part then is drunk. Would it were all,
That it might go on wheels!

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Drink thou; increase the reels.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Come.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels ho!
Here’s to Caesar!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: I could well forbear’t.
It’s monstrous labor when I wash my brain
And it grow fouler.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Be a child o’ th’ time.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Possess it, I’ll make answer.
But I had rather fast from all, four days,
Than drink so much in one.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Ha, my brave emperor!
Shall we dance now the Egyptian bacchanals
And celebrate our drink?

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: Let’s ha’t, good soldier.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Come, let’s all take hands,
Till that the conquering wine hath steep’d our sense
In soft and delicate Lethe.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: All take hands.
Make battery to our ears with the loud music;
The while I’ll place you, then the boy shall sing.
The holding every man shall bear as loud
As his strong sides can volley.
speech.stagedir: Enobarbus places them hand in hand.
speech.line: Come, thou monarch of the vine,
Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!
In thy fats our cares be drown’d,
With thy grapes our hairs be crown’d!
Cup us till the world go round,
Cup us till the world go round!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: What would you more? Pompey, good night. Good brother,
Let me request you off, our graver business
Frowns at this levity. Gentle lords, let’s part,
You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarb
Is weaker than the wine, and mine own tongue
Spleets what it speaks; the wild disguise hath almost
Antick’d us all. What needs more words? Good night.
Good Antony, your hand.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: I’ll try you on the shore.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: And shall, sir, give ’s your hand.

speech.speaker: POM.
speech.line: O Antony,
You have my father’s house—But what, we are friends?
Come down into the boat.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Take heed you fall not.
speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but Enobarbus and Menas.
speech.line: Menas, I’ll not on shore.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: No, to my cabin.
These drums, these trumpets, flutes! What!
Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell
To these great fellows. Sound and be hang’d, sound out!

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Hoo, says ’a. There’s my cap.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Ho, noble captain, come.

scene.scenepersonae: (Ventidius, Silius, Romans, Officers, Soldiers, the dead body of Pacorus)
scene.scenedescription: Ventidius has beaten the Parthian host, but decides not to pursue them further.
scene.stagedir: Enter Ventidius as it were in triumph with Silius and other Romans, Officers, and Soldiers, the dead body of Pacorus borne before him.

speech.speaker: VEN.
speech.line: Now, darting Parthia, art thou strook, and now
Pleas’d Fortune does of Marcus Crassus’ death
Make me revenger. Bear the King’s son’s body
Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes,
Pays this for Marcus Crassus.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Noble Ventidius,
Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm,
The fugitive Parthians follow. Spur through Media,
Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither
The routed fly; so thy grand captain, Antony,
Shall set thee on triumphant chariots, and
Put garlands on thy head.

speech.speaker: VEN.
speech.line: O Silius, Silius,
I have done enough; a lower place, note well,
May make too great an act. For learn this, Silius:
Better to leave undone, than by our deed
Acquire too high a fame when him we serve’s away.
Caesar and Antony have ever won
More in their officer than person. Sossius,
One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant,
For quick accumulation of renown,
Which he achiev’d by th’ minute, lost his favor.
Who does i’ th’ wars more than his captain can
Becomes his captain’s captain; and ambition
(The soldier’s virtue) rather makes choice of loss
Than gain which darkens him.
I could do more to do Antonius good,
But ’twould offend him; and in his offense
Should my performance perish.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Thou hast, Ventidius, that
Without the which a soldier and his sword
Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony?

speech.speaker: VEN.
speech.line: I’ll humbly signify what in his name,
That magical word of war, we have effected;
How with his banners, and his well-paid ranks,
The ne’er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia
We have jaded out o’ th’ field.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Where is he now?

speech.speaker: VEN.
speech.line: He purposeth to Athens, whither, with what haste
The weight we must convey with ’s will permit,
We shall appear before him. On, there, pass along!

scene.scenelocation: Rome. An ante-chamber in Octavius Caesar’s house.
scene.scenedescription: Caesar bids farewell to Octavia and Antony, who are leaving Rome for Athens.
scene.stagedir: Enter Agrippa at one door, Enobarbus at another.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: What, are the brothers parted?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: They have dispatch’d with Pompey, he is gone;
The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps
To part from Rome; Caesar is sad, and Lepidus,
Since Pompey’s feast, as Menas says, is troubled
With the green-sickness.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: ’Tis a noble Lepidus.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: A very fine one. O, how he loves Caesar!

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Caesar? Why, he’s the Jupiter of men.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: What’s Antony? The god of Jupiter.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Spake you of Caesar? How, the nonpareil!

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: O Antony! O thou Arabian bird!

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Would you praise Caesar, say “Caesar,” go no further.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Indeed he plied them both with excellent praises.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: But he loves Caesar best, yet he loves Antony.
Hoo, hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot
Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number, hoo!
His love to Antony. But as for Caesar,
Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Both he loves.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: They are his shards, and he their beetle, so.
This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.
speech.stagedir: Enter Caesar, Antony, Lepidus, and Octavia.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: No further, sir.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: You take from me a great part of myself;
Use me well in’t. Sister, prove such a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest band
Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony,
Let not the piece of virtue which is set
Betwixt us, as the cement of our love
To keep it builded, be the ram to batter
The fortress of it; for better might we
Have lov’d without this mean, if on both parts
This be not cherish’d.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Make me not offended
In your distrust.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: I have said.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: You shall not find,
Though you be therein curious, the least cause
For what you seem to fear. So the gods keep you,
And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends!
We will here part.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well,
The elements be kind to thee, and make
Thy spirits all of comfort! Fare thee well.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: My noble brother!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: The April’s in her eyes, it is love’s spring,
And these the showers to bring it on. Be cheerful.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Sir, look well to my husband’s house; and—

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: What,
Octavia?

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: I’ll tell you in your ear.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart inform her tongue—the swan’s down feather,
That stands upon the swell at the full of tide,
And neither way inclines.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Will Caesar weep?

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: He has a cloud in ’s face.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: He were the worse for that were he a horse;
So is he being a man.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Why, Enobarbus?
When Antony found Julius Caesar dead,
He cried almost to roaring; and he wept
When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: That year indeed he was troubled with a rheum;
What willingly he did confound he wail’d,
Believe’t—till I weep too.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: No, sweet Octavia,
You shall hear from me still; the time shall not
Outgo my thinking on you.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Come, sir, come,
I’ll wrastle with you in my strength of love.
Look, here I have you, thus I let you go,
And give you to the gods.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Adieu, be happy.

speech.speaker: LEP.
speech.line: Let all the number of the stars give light
To thy fair way.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Farewell.

scene.scenedescription: Cleopatra gets a diplomatically unfavorable description of Octavia from the messenger.
scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Where is the fellow?

speech.speaker: ALEX.
speech.line: Half afeard to come.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Go to, go to. Come hither, sir.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Egyptian Messenger as before.

speech.speaker: ALEX.
speech.line: Good Majesty!
Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you
But when you are well pleas’d.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: That Herod’s head
I’ll have; but how, when Antony is gone,
Through whom I might command it? Come thou near.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Most gracious Majesty!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Didst thou behold Octavia?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Ay, dread Queen.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Where?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Madam, in Rome;
I look’d her in the face, and saw her led
Between her brother and Mark Antony.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Is she as tall as me?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: She is not, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Didst hear her speak? Is she shrill-tongu’d or low?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Madam, I heard her speak; she is low-voic’d.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: That’s not so good. He cannot like her long.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Like her? O Isis! ’Tis impossible.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I think so, Charmian: dull of tongue, and dwarfish.
What majesty is in her gait? Remember,
If e’er thou look’st on majesty.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: She creeps;
Her motion and her station are as one;
She shows a body rather than a life,
A statue, than a breather.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Is this certain?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Or I have no observance.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Three in Egypt
Cannot make better note.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: He’s very knowing,
I do perceive’t. There’s nothing in her yet.
The fellow has good judgment.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Excellent.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Guess at her years, I prithee.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Madam,
She was a widow—

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Widow? Charmian, hark.

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: And I do think she’s thirty.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Bear’st thou her face in mind? Is’t long or round?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Round, even to faultiness.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.
Her hair, what color?

speech.speaker: EGYPT. MESS.
speech.line: Brown, madam; and her forehead
As low as she would wish it.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: There’s gold for thee,
Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.
I will employ thee back again; I find thee
Most fit for business. Go, make thee ready,
Our letters are prepar’d.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: A proper man.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Indeed he is so; I repent me much
That so I harried him. Why, methinks, by him,
This creature’s no such thing.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Nothing, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: The man hath seen some majesty, and should know.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend!
And serving you so long!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I have one thing more to ask him yet, good Charmian—
But ’tis no matter, thou shalt bring him to me
Where I will write. All may be well enough.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: I warrant you, madam.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. A room in Antony’s house.
scene.scenedescription: Octavia tries to pacify Antony, who is raging at Caesar’s insulting actions. She goes to Rome as a conciliator.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Nay, nay, Octavia, not only that—
That were excusable, that, and thousands more
Of semblable import—but he hath wag’d
New wars ’gainst Pompey; made his will, and read it
To public ear;
Spoke scantly of me; when perforce he could not
But pay me terms of honor, cold and sickly
He vented them, most narrow measure lent me;
When the best hint was given him, he not took’t,
Or did it from his teeth.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: O my good lord,
Believe not all, or if you must believe,
Stomach not all. A more unhappy lady,
If this division chance, ne’er stood between,
Praying for both parts.
The good gods will mock me presently,
When I shall pray, “O, bless my lord and husband!”
Undo that prayer, by crying out as loud,
“O, bless my brother!” Husband win, win brother,
Prays, and destroys the prayer, no midway
’Twixt these extremes at all.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Gentle Octavia,
Let your best love draw to that point which seeks
Best to preserve it. If I lose mine honor,
I lose myself; better I were not yours
Than yours so branchless. But as you requested,
Yourself shall go between ’s. The mean time, lady,
I’ll raise the preparation of a war
Shall stain your brother. Make your soonest haste;
So your desires are yours.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Thanks to my lord.
The Jove of power make me most weak, most weak,
Your reconciler! Wars ’twixt you twain would be
As if the world should cleave, and that slain men
Should solder up the rift.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: When it appears to you where this begins,
Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults
Can never be so equal that your love
Can equally move with them. Provide your going,
Choose your own company, and command what cost
Your heart has mind to.

scene.scenelocation: Athens. Another room in Antony’s house.
scene.scenedescription: Lepidus has been displaced from power by Caesar, and Pompey beaten. Now the battle for world supremacy is between Antony and Caesar.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: How now, friend Eros?

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: There’s strange news come, sir.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: What, man?

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: This is old, what is the success?

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Caesar, having made use of him in the wars ’gainst Pompey, presently denied him rivality, would not let him partake in the glory of the action, and not resting here, accuses him of letters he had formerly wrote to Pompey; upon his own appeal, seizes him. So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps—no more,
And throw between them all the food thou hast,
They’ll grind th’ one the other. Where’s Antony?

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: He’s walking in the garden—thus, and spurns
The rush that lies before him; cries, “Fool Lepidus!”
And threats the throat of that his officer
That murd’red Pompey.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Our great navy’s rigg’d.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: For Italy and Caesar. More, Domitius,
My lord desires you presently; my news
I might have told hereafter.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: ’Twill be naught,
But let it be. Bring me to Antony.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Come, sir.

scene.scenedescription: Caesar reports on how Antony has named himself and Cleopatra emperors of the Orient. Octavia comes to Caesar, who informs her that Antony is not in Athens, where she left him, but in Alexandria, with Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Contemning Rome, he has done all this and more
In Alexandria. Here’s the manner of’t:
I’ th’ market-place, on a tribunal silver’d,
Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold
Were publicly enthron’d. At the feet sat
Caesarion, whom they call my father’s son,
And all the unlawful issue that their lust
Since then hath made between them. Unto her
He gave the stablishment of Egypt, made her
Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia,
Absolute queen.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: This in the public eye?

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: I’ th’ common show-place, where they exercise.
His sons he there proclaim’d the kings of kings:
Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia
He gave to Alexander; to Ptolomy he assign’d
Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia. She
In th’ abiliments of the goddess Isis
That day appear’d; and oft before gave audience,
As ’tis reported, so.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: Let Rome be thus
Inform’d.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Who, queasy with his insolence
Already, will their good thoughts call from him.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: The people knows it, and have now receiv’d
His accusations.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Who does he accuse?

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Caesar, and that having in Sicily
Sextus Pompeius spoil’d, we had not rated him
His part o’ th’ isle. Then does he say he lent me
Some shipping unrestor’d. Lastly, he frets
That Lepidus of the triumpherate
Should be depos’d; and being, that we detain
All his revenue.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Sir, this should be answer’d.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: ’Tis done already, and the messenger gone.
I have told him Lepidus was grown too cruel,
That he his high authority abus’d,
And did deserve his change. For what I have conquer’d,
I grant him part; but then, in his Armenia
And other of his conquer’d kingdoms, I
Demand the like.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: He’ll never yield to that.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Nor must not then be yielded to in this.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Hail, Caesar, and my lord! Hail, most dear Caesar!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: That ever I should call thee castaway!

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: You have not call’d me so, nor have you cause.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Why have you stol’n upon us thus? You come not
Like Caesar’s sister. The wife of Antony
Should have an army for an usher, and
The neighs of horse to tell of her approach,
Long ere she did appear; the trees by th’ way
Should have borne men, and expectation fainted,
Longing for what it had not; nay, the dust
Should have ascended to the roof of heaven,
Rais’d by your populous troops. But you are come
A market-maid to Rome, and have prevented
The ostentation of our love, which, left unshown,
Is often left unlov’d. We should have met you
By sea and land, supplying every stage
With an augmented greeting.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Good my lord,
To come thus was I not constrain’d, but did it
On my free will. My lord, Mark Antony,
Hearing that you prepar’d for war, acquainted
My grieved ear withal; whereon I begg’d
His pardon for return.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Which soon he granted,
Being an abstract ’tween his lust and him.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Do not say so, my lord.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: I have eyes upon him,
And his affairs come to me on the wind.
Where is he now?

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: My lord, in Athens.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: No, my most wronged sister, Cleopatra
Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his empire
Up to a whore, who now are levying
The kings o’ th’ earth for war. He hath assembled
Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus
Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King
Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas;
King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont;
Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King
Of Comagena; Polemon and Amyntas,
The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia,
With a more larger list of sceptres.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Ay me, most wretched,
That have my heart parted betwixt two friends
That does afflict each other!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Welcome hither!
Your letters did withhold our breaking forth,
Till we perceiv’d both how you were wrong led
And we in negligent danger. Cheer your heart,
Be you not troubled with the time, which drives
O’er your content these strong necessities,
But let determin’d things to destiny
Hold unbewail’d their way. Welcome to Rome,
Nothing more dear to me. You are abus’d
Beyond the mark of thought; and the high gods,
To do you justice, makes his ministers
Of us and those that love you. Best of comfort,
And ever welcome to us.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Welcome, lady.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: Welcome, dear madam,
Each heart in Rome does love and pity you;
Only th’ adulterous Antony, most large
In his abominations, turns you off,
And gives his potent regiment to a trull
That noises it against us.

speech.speaker: OCT.
speech.line: Is it so, sir?

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Most certain. Sister, welcome. Pray you
Be ever known to patience. My dear’st sister!

scene.scenepersonae: (Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Antony, Canidius, Second Roman Messenger, Scarus)
scene.scenedescription: The plain-spoken Enobarbus tells Cleopatra she shouldn’t be at the army’s camp, as she will distract Antony. Foolhardily, Antony decides to fight Caesar on sea, where Caesar is much the stronger.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I will be even with thee, doubt it not.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: But why, why, why?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Thou hast forespoke my being in these wars,
And say’st it is not fit.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Well; is it, is it?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: If not denounc’d against us, why should not we
Be there in person?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Well, I could reply:
If we should serve with horse and mares together,
The horse were merely lost; the mares would bear
A soldier and his horse.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What is’t you say?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Your presence needs must puzzle Antony,
Take from his heart, take from his brain, from ’s time,
What should not then be spar’d. He is already
Traduc’d for levity, and ’tis said in Rome
That Photinus an eunuch and your maids
Manage this war.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Sink Rome, and their tongues rot
That speak against us! A charge we bear i’ th’ war,
And as the president of my kingdom will
Appear there for a man. Speak not against it,
I will not stay behind.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Nay, I have done,
Here comes the Emperor.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Is it not strange, Canidius,
That from Tarentum and Brundusium
He could so quickly cut the Ionian Sea,
And take in Toryne? You have heard on’t, sweet?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Celerity is never more admir’d
Than by the negligent.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: A good rebuke,
Which might have well becom’d the best of men,
To taunt at slackness. Canidius, we
Will fight with him by sea.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: By sea, what else?

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Why will my lord do so?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: For that he dares us to’t.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: So hath my lord dar’d him to single fight.

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia,
Where Caesar fought with Pompey. But these offers,
Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off,
And so should you.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Your ships are not well mann’d,
Your mariners are muleters, reapers, people
Ingross’d by swift impress. In Caesar’s fleet
Are those that often have ’gainst Pompey fought;
Their ships are yare, yours heavy. No disgrace
Shall fall you for refusing him at sea,
Being prepar’d for land.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: By sea, by sea.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Most worthy sir, you therein throw away
The absolute soldiership you have by land,
Distract your army, which doth most consist
Of war-mark’d footmen, leave unexecuted
Your own renowned knowledge, quite forgo
The way which promises assurance, and
Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard,
From firm security.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I’ll fight at sea.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I have sixty sails, Caesar none better.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Our overplus of shipping will we burn,
And, with the rest full-mann’d, from th’ head of Actium
Beat th’ approaching Caesar. But if we fail,
We then can do’t at land.
Thy business?

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. MESS.
speech.line: The news is true, my lord: he is descried;
Caesar has taken Toryne.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Can he be there in person? ’Tis impossible
Strange that his power should be. Canidius,
Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land,
And our twelve thousand horse. We’ll to our ship,
Away, my Thetis!
How now, worthy soldier?

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea,
Trust not to rotten planks. Do you misdoubt
This sword, and these my wounds? Let th’ Egyptians
And the Phoenicians go a-ducking; we
Have us’d to conquer standing on the earth,
And fighting foot to foot.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Well, well, away!

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: By Hercules, I think I am i’ th’ right.

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Soldier, thou art; but his whole action grows
Not in the power on’t. So our leader’s led,
And we are women’s men.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: You keep by land
The legions and the horse whole, do you not?

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius,
Publicola, and Caelius are for sea;
But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar’s
Carries beyond belief.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: While he was yet in Rome,
His power went out in such distractions as
Beguil’d all spies.

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Who’s his lieutenant, hear you?

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: They say, one Taurus.

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Well I know the man.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. MESS.
speech.line: The Emperor calls Canidius.

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: With news the time’s with labor, and throes forth
Each minute some.

scene.scenedescription: Caesar warns Taurus, the commander of his land forces, not to attack until the battle at sea is won.
scene.stagedir: Enter Caesar with his army and Taurus, marching.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Taurus!

speech.speaker: TAUR.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Strike not by land, keep whole, provoke not battle
Till we have done at sea. Do not exceed
The prescript of this scroll. Our fortune lies
Upon this jump.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the plain near Actium.
scene.scenedescription: Antony gives Enobarbus his directions.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Set we our squadrons on yond side o’ th’ hill,
In eye of Caesar’s battle, from which place
We may the number of the ships behold,
And so proceed accordingly.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the plain near Actium.
scene.scenedescription: Antony’s commanders witness the battle lost as Cleopatra flees and Antony follows her. Two of them decide to no longer follow Antony.
scene.stagedir: Canidius marcheth with his land army one way over the stage, and Taurus, the lieutenant of Caesar, the other way. After their going in, is heard the noise of a sea-fight.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Naught, naught, all naught! I can behold no longer.
Th’ Antoniad, the Egyptian admiral,
With all their sixty, fly and turn the rudder.
To see’t mine eyes are blasted.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: Gods and goddesses,
All the whole synod of them!

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: What’s thy passion?

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: The greater cantle of the world is lost
With very ignorance, we have kiss’d away
Kingdoms and provinces.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: How appears the fight?

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: On our side like the token’d pestilence,
Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt
(Whom leprosy o’ertake!) i’ th’ midst o’ th’ fight,
When vantage like a pair of twins appear’d,
Both as the same, or rather ours the elder—
The breeze upon her, like a cow in June—
Hoists sails and flies.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: That I beheld.
Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not
Endure a further view.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: She once being loof’d,
The noble ruin of her magic, Antony,
Claps on his sea-wing, and (like a doting mallard),
Leaving the fight in heighth, flies after her.
I never saw an action of such shame;
Experience, manhood, honor, ne’er before
Did violate so itself.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Alack, alack!

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath,
And sinks most lamentably. Had our general
Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
O, he has given example for our flight,
Most grossly, by his own!

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Ay, are you thereabouts?
Why then good night indeed.

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: ’Tis easy to’t, and there I will attend
What further comes.

speech.speaker: CAN.
speech.line: To Caesar will I render
My legions and my horse: six kings already
Show me the way of yielding.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: I’ll yet follow
The wounded chance of Antony, though my reason
Sits in the wind against me.

scene.scenepersonae: (Antony, Antony’s First Attendant, Antony’s Second Attendant, Cleopatra, Charmian, Eros, Iras)
scene.scenedescription: Antony is thoroughly ashamed of his weakness in fleeing after Cleopatra. The queen comes to beg his pardon. Though he rages at her, Antony loves Cleopatra too much not to.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Hark, the land bids me tread no more upon’t,
It is asham’d to bear me. Friends, come hither:
I am so lated in the world, that I
Have lost my way forever. I have a ship
Laden with gold, take that, divide it; fly,
And make your peace with Caesar.

speech.speaker: ALL. ANT. ATT.
speech.line: Fly? Not we.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards
To run and show their shoulders. Friends, be gone,
I have myself resolv’d upon a course
Which has no need of you. Be gone.
My treasure’s in the harbor; take it. O,
I follow’d that I blush to look upon.
My very hairs do mutiny; for the white
Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them
For fear and doting. Friends, be gone, you shall
Have letters from me to some friends that will
Sweep your way for you. Pray you look not sad,
Nor make replies of loathness; take the hint
Which my despair proclaims: let that be left
Which leaves itself. To the sea-side straightway;
I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
Leave me, I pray, a little; pray you now,
Nay, do so; for indeed I have lost command,
Therefore I pray you. I’ll see you by and by.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra led by Charmian and Eros, Iras following.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Nay, gentle madam, to him, comfort him.

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: Do, most dear Queen.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Do? Why, what else?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Let me sit down. O Juno!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: No, no, no, no, no.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: See you here, sir?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: O fie, fie, fie!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Madam!

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: Madam, O good Empress!

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Sir, sir!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Yes, my lord, yes; he at Philippi kept
His sword e’en like a dancer, while I strook
The lean and wrinkled Cassius, and ’twas I
That the mad Brutus ended. He alone
Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practice had
In the brave squares of war; yet now—No matter.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Ah, stand by.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: The Queen, my lord, the Queen.

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: Go to him, madam, speak to him,
He’s unqualited with very shame.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Well then, sustain me. O!

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Most noble sir, arise, the Queen approaches.
Her head’s declin’d, and death will seize her, but
Your comfort makes the rescue.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I have offended reputation,
A most unnoble swerving.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Sir, the Queen.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: O, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See
How I convey my shame out of thine eyes
By looking back what I have left behind
’Stroy’d in dishonor.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O my lord, my lord,
Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought
You would have followed.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Egypt, thou knew’st too well
My heart was to thy rudder tied by th’ strings,
And thou shouldst tow me after. O’er my spirit
Thy full supremacy thou knew’st, and that
Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods
Command me.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O, my pardon!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Now I must
To the young man send humble treaties, dodge
And palter in the shifts of lowness, who
With half the bulk o’ th’ world play’d as I pleas’d,
Making and marring fortunes. You did know
How much you were my conqueror, and that
My sword, made weak by my affection, would
Obey it on all cause.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Pardon, pardon!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Fall not a tear, I say, one of them rates
All that is won and lost. Give me a kiss.
Even this repays me. We sent our schoolmaster,
Is ’a come back? Love, I am full of lead.
Some wine, within there, and our viands! Fortune knows
We scorn her most when most she offers blows.

scene.scenedescription: Antony’s schoolmaster bears a humble offer of peace to Caesar, but Caesar wants him driven out of Egypt.
scene.stagedir: Enter Caesar, Agrippa, Thidias, and Dolabella, with others.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Let him appear that’s come from Antony.
Know you him?

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Caesar, ’tis his schoolmaster,
An argument that he is pluck’d, when hither
He sends so poor a pinion of his wing,
Which had superfluous kings for messengers
Not many moons gone by.

scene.stagedir: Enter Schoolmaster as Ambassador from Antony.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Approach and speak.

speech.speaker: AMB.
speech.line: Such as I am, I come from Antony.
I was of late as petty to his ends
As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf
To his grand sea.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Be’t so, declare thine office.

speech.speaker: AMB.
speech.line: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and
Requires to live in Egypt, which not granted,
He lessons his requests, and to thee sues
To let him breathe between the heavens and earth,
A private man in Athens: this for him.
Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness,
Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves
The circle of the Ptolomies for her heirs,
Now hazarded to thy grace.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: For Antony,
I have no ears to his request. The Queen
Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she
From Egypt drive her all-disgraced friend,
Or take his life there. This if she perform,
She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.

speech.speaker: AMB.
speech.line: Fortune pursue thee!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Bring him through the bands.
To try thy eloquence, now ’tis time; dispatch.
From Antony win Cleopatra, promise,
And in our name, what she requires; add more,
From thine invention, offers. Women are not
In their best fortunes strong, but want will perjure
The ne’er-touch’d vestal. Try thy cunning, Thidias,
Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we
Will answer as a law.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: Caesar, I go.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw,
And what thou think’st his very action speaks
In every power that moves.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: Caesar, I shall.

scene.scenepersonae: (Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, Iras, Schoolmaster as Ambassador, Antony, First Egyptian Servant, Second Egyptian Servant, Thidias)
scene.scenedescription: Antony challenges Caesar to single combat again. Enobarbus begins to doubt his allegiance to Antony. Thidias comes from Caesar to ask Cleopatra to betray Antony. Antony has Thidias whipped, and resolves to fight again.
scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, and Iras.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Think, and die.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Is Antony or we in fault for this?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Antony only, that would make his will
Lord of his reason. What though you fled
From that great face of war, whose several ranges
Frighted each other? Why should he follow?
The itch of his affection should not then
Have nick’d his captainship, at such a point,
When half to half the world oppos’d, he being
The mered question. ’Twas a shame no less
Than was his loss, to course your flying flags,
And leave his navy gazing.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Prithee peace.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Is that his answer?

speech.speaker: AMB.
speech.line: Ay, my lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she
Will yield us up.

speech.speaker: AMB.
speech.line: He says so.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Let her know’t.
To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head,
And he will fill thy wishes to the brim
With principalities.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: That head, my lord?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: To him again, tell him he wears the rose
Of youth upon him; from which the world should note
Something particular. His coin, ships, legions,
May be a coward’s, whose ministers would prevail
Under the service of a child as soon
As i’ th’ command of Caesar. I dare him therefore
To lay his gay comparisons apart,
And answer me declin’d, sword against sword,
Ourselves alone. I’ll write it. Follow me.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Yes, like enough! High-battled Caesar will
Unstate his happiness, and be stag’d to th’ show
Against a sworder! I see men’s judgments are
A parcel of their fortunes, and things outward
Do draw the inward quality after them,
To suffer all alike. That he should dream,
Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will
Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdu’d
His judgment too.

speech.speaker: 1. EGYPT. SERV.
speech.line: A messenger from Caesar.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What, no more ceremony? See, my women,
Against the blown rose may they stop their nose
That kneel’d unto the buds. Admit him, sir.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Mine honesty and I begin to square.
The loyalty well held to fools does make
Our faith mere folly; yet he that can endure
To follow with allegiance a fall’n lord
Does conquer him that did his master conquer,
And earns a place i’ th’ story.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Caesar’s will?

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: Hear it apart.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: None but friends: say boldly.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: So haply are they friends to Antony.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has,
Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master
Will leap to be his friend; for us, you know
Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar’s.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: So.
Thus then, thou most renown’d: Caesar entreats
Not to consider in what case thou stand’st
Further than he is Caesar.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Go on: right royal.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: He knows that you embrace not Antony
As you did love, but as you fear’d him.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O!

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: The scars upon your honor, therefore, he
Does pity, as constrained blemishes,
Not as deserved.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: He is a god and knows
What is most right. Mine honor was not yielded,
But conquer’d merely.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: To be sure of that,
I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky
That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for
Thy dearest quit thee.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: Shall I say to Caesar
What you require of him? For he partly begs
To be desir’d to give. It much would please him,
That of his fortunes you should make a staff
To lean upon; but it would warm his spirits
To hear from me you had left Antony,
And put yourself under his shroud,
The universal landlord.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What’s your name?

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: My name is Thidias.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Most kind messenger,
Say to great Caesar this in deputation:
I kiss his conqu’ring hand. Tell him, I am prompt
To lay my crown at ’s feet, and there to kneel.
Tell him, from his all-obeying breath I hear
The doom of Egypt.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: ’Tis your noblest course.
Wisdom and fortune combating together,
If that the former dare but what it can,
No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay
My duty on your hand.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Your Caesar’s father oft
(When he hath mus’d of taking kingdoms in)
Bestow’d his lips on that unworthy place,
As it rain’d kisses.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Favors? By Jove that thunders!
What art thou, fellow?

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: One that but performs
The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest
To have command obey’d.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: You will be whipt.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Approach there!—Ah, you kite!—Now gods and devils!
Authority melts from me. Of late, when I cried “Ho!”
Like boys unto a muss, kings would start forth
And cry, “Your will?”—Have you no ears?—I am
Antony yet.
speech.stagedir: Enter First Egyptian Servant, others following.
speech.line: Take hence this Jack and whip him.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: ’Tis better playing with a lion’s whelp
Than with an old one dying.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Moon and stars!
Whip him. Were’t twenty of the greatest tributaries
That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them
So saucy with the hand of she here—what’s her name,
Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows,
Till like a boy you see him cringe his face,
And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.

speech.speaker: THID.
speech.line: Mark Antony—

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Tug him away. Being whipt,
Bring him again; the Jack of Caesar’s shall
Bear us an arrant to him.
You were half blasted ere I knew you; ha?
Have I my pillow left unpress’d in Rome,
Forborne the getting of a lawful race,
And by a gem of women, to be abus’d
By one that looks on feeders?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Good my lord—

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: You have been a boggler ever,
But when we in our viciousness grow hard
(O misery on’t!), the wise gods seel our eyes,
In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us
Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut
To our confusion.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O, is’t come to this?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I found you as a morsel, cold upon
Dead Caesar’s trencher; nay, you were a fragment
Of Cneius Pompey’s—besides what hotter hours,
Unregist’red in vulgar fame, you have
Luxuriously pick’d out; for I am sure,
Though you can guess what temperance should be,
You know not what it is.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Wherefore is this?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: To let a fellow that will take rewards
And say “God quit you!” be familiar with
My playfellow, your hand, this kingly seal
And plighter of high hearts! O that I were
Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar
The horned herd! For I have savage cause,
And to proclaim it civilly were like
A halter’d neck which does the hangman thank
For being yare about him.
speech.stagedir: Enter First Egyptian Servant with Thidias.
speech.line: Is he whipt?

speech.speaker: 1. EGYPT. SERV.
speech.line: Soundly, my lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Cried he? And begg’d ’a pardon?

speech.speaker: 1. EGYPT. SERV.
speech.line: He did ask favor.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: If that thy father live, let him repent
Thou wast not made his daughter, and be thou sorry
To follow Caesar in his triumph, since
Thou hast been whipt for following him. Henceforth
The white hand of a lady fever thee,
Shake thou to look on’t. Get thee back to Caesar,
Tell him thy entertainment. Look thou say
He makes me angry with him; for he seems
Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,
Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry,
And at this time most easy ’tis to do’t:
When my good stars, that were my former guides,
Have empty left their orbs, and shot their fires
Into th’ abysm of hell. If he mislike
My speech and what is done, tell him he has
Hipparchus, my enfranched bondman, whom
He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture,
As he shall like, to quit me. Urge it thou:
Hence with thy stripes, be gone!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Have you done yet?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Alack, our terrene moon
Is now eclips’d, and it portends alone
The fall of Antony!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I must stay his time.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes
With one that ties his points?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Not know me yet?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Cold-hearted toward me?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Ah, dear, if I be so,
From my cold heart let heaven engender hail,
And poison it in the source, and the first stone
Drop in my neck; as it determines, so
Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite,
Till by degrees the memory of my womb,
Together with my brave Egyptians all,
By the discandying of this pelleted storm,
Lie graveless, till the flies and gnats of Nile
Have buried them for prey!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I am satisfied.
Caesar sets down in Alexandria, where
I will oppose his fate. Our force by land
Hath nobly held; our sever’d navy too
Have knit again, and fleet, threat’ning most sea-like.
Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady?
If from the field I shall return once more
To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood;
I and my sword will earn our chronicle.
There’s hope in’t yet.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: That’s my brave lord!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I will be treble-sinew’d, hearted, breath’d,
And fight maliciously; for when mine hours
Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives
Of me for jests; but now I’ll set my teeth,
And send to darkness all that stop me. Come,
Let’s have one other gaudy night. Call to me
All my sad captains, fill our bowls once more;
Let’s mock the midnight bell.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: It is my birthday,
I had thought t’ have held it poor; but since my lord
Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: We will yet do well.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Call all his noble captains to my lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Do so, we’ll speak to them, and tonight I’ll force
The wine peep through their scars. Come on, my queen,
There’s sap in’t yet. The next time I do fight,
I’ll make death love me; for I will contend
Even with his pestilent scythe.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Now he’ll outstare the lightning: to be furious
Is to be frighted out of fear, and in that mood
The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still
A diminution in our captain’s brain
Restores his heart. When valor preys on reason,
It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek
Some way to leave him.

scene.scenedescription: Caesar laughs at Antony’s challenge to personal combat.
scene.stagedir: Enter Caesar, Agrippa, and Maecenas, with his army; Caesar reading a letter.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: He calls me boy, and chides as he had power
To beat me out of Egypt. My messenger
He hath whipt with rods, dares me to personal combat,
Caesar to Antony. Let the old ruffian know
I have many other ways to die; mean time
Laugh at his challenge.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: Caesar must think,
When one so great begins to rage, he’s hunted
Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now
Make boot of his distraction: never anger
Made good guard for itself.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Let our best heads
Know that tomorrow the last of many battles
We mean to fight. Within our files there are,
Of those that serv’d Mark Antony but late,
Enough to fetch him in. See it done,
And feast the army; we have store to do’t,
And they have earn’d the waste. Poor Antony!

scene.scenepersonae: (Antony, Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, Iras, Alexas, Antony’s First Attendant, Antony’s Second Attendant)
scene.scenedescription: Antony praises his faithful servants, bringing them to tears. He prepares for a great feast before the crucial battle.
scene.stagedir: Enter Antony, Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, Iras, Alexas, with others.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: He will not fight with me, Domitius?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Why should he not?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,
He is twenty men to one.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Tomorrow, soldier,
By sea and land I’ll fight; or I will live,
Or bathe my dying honor in the blood
Shall make it live again. Woo’t thou fight well?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: I’ll strike, and cry, “Take all!”

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Well said, come on.
Call forth my household servants, let’s tonight
Be bounteous at our meal.
Give me thy hand,
Thou hast been rightly honest—so hast thou—
Thou—and thou—and thou. You have serv’d me well,
And kings have been your fellows.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What means this?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: ’Tis one of those odd tricks which sorrow shoots
Out of the mind.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: And thou art honest too.
I wish I could be made so many men,
And all of you clapp’d up together in
An Antony, that I might do you service
So good as you have done.

speech.speaker: ALL. ANT. ATT.
speech.line: The gods forbid!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.
Scant not my cups, and make as much of me
As when mine empire was your fellow too,
And suffer’d my command.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What does he mean?

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: To make his followers weep.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Tend me tonight;
May be it is the period of your duty;
Haply you shall not see me more, or if,
A mangled shadow. Perchance tomorrow
You’ll serve another master. I look on you
As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends,
I turn you not away, but like a master
Married to your good service, stay till death.
Tend me tonight two hours, I ask no more,
And the gods yield you for’t!

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: What mean you, sir,
To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep,
And I, an ass, am onion-ey’d. For shame,
Transform us not to women.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Ho, ho, ho!
Now the witch take me, if I meant it thus!
Grace grow where those drops fall, my hearty friends!
You take me in too dolorous a sense,
For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you
To burn this night with torches. Know, my hearts,
I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you
Where rather I’ll expect victorious life
Than death and honor. Let’s to supper, come,
And drown consideration.

scene.scenepersonae: (Antony’s First Soldier, Antony’s Second Soldier, Antony’s Third Soldier, Antony’s Fourth Soldier)
scene.scenedescription: Soldiers mounting guard hear otherworldly music, that they conclude is the god Hercules abandoning Antony.
scene.stagedir: Enter a company of Antony’s Soldiers.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Brother, good night; tomorrow is the day.

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: It will determine one way; fare you well.
Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Nothing. What news?

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Belike ’tis but a rumor. Good night to you.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Well, sir, good night.

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Soldiers, have careful watch.

speech.speaker: ANT. 3. SOLD.
speech.line: And you. Good night, good night.

scene.stagedir: They place themselves in every corner of the stage.

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Here we. And if tomorrow
Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope
Our landmen will stand up.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: ’Tis a brave army,
And full of purpose.

scene.stagedir: Music of the hoboys is under the stage.

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Peace, what noise?

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: List, list!

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: Hark!

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Music i’ th’ air.

speech.speaker: ANT. 3. SOLD.
speech.line: Under the earth.

speech.speaker: ANT. 4. SOLD.
speech.line: It signs well, does it not?

speech.speaker: ANT. 3. SOLD.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Peace, I say.
What should this mean?

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: ’Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony lov’d,
Now leaves him.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Walk; let’s see if other watchmen
Do hear what we do.

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. SOLD.
speech.line: How now, masters?

speech.speaker: ALL. ANT. SOLD.
speech.line: How now?
How now? Do you hear this?

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Ay, is’t not strange?

speech.speaker: ANT. 3. SOLD.
speech.line: Do you hear, masters? Do you hear?

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Follow the noise so far as we have quarter;
Let’s see how it will give off.

speech.speaker: ALL. ANT. SOLD.
speech.line: Content. ’Tis strange.

scene.scenepersonae: (Antony, Cleopatra, Charmian, Scarus, Soldiers, Captain of Antony’s Army)
scene.scenedescription: Cleopatra clumsily helps Antony put on his armor. He leaves to battle, and Cleopatra thinks of how things could have turned out differently.
scene.stagedir: Enter Antony and Cleopatra, Charmian, with others.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Eros, mine armor, Eros!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Sleep a little.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: No, my chuck. Eros, come, mine armor, Eros!
Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.
If Fortune be not ours today, it is
Because we brave her. Come.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll help too.
What’s this for?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Ah, let be, let be! Thou art
The armorer of my heart. False, false; this, this.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Sooth law, I’ll help. Thus it must be.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Well, well,
We shall thrive now. Seest thou, my good fellow?
Go, put on thy defenses.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Briefly, sir.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Is not this buckled well?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Rarely, rarely:
He that unbuckles this, till we do please
To daff’t for our repose, shall hear a storm.
Thou fumblest, Eros, and my queen’s a squire
More tight at this than thou; dispatch. O love,
That thou couldst see my wars today, and knew’st
