The royal occupation, thou shouldst see
A workman in’t.
Good morrow to thee, welcome.
Thou look’st like him that knows a warlike charge.
To business that we love we rise betime,
And go to’t with delight.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: A thousand, sir,
Early though’t be, have on their riveted trim,
And at the port expect you.

scene.stagedir: Enter Captain of Antony’s Army, Captains and Soldiers.

speech.speaker: CAPT. ANT. ARMY.
speech.line: The morn is fair. Good morrow, general.

speech.speaker: ALL. ANT. SOLD.
speech.line: Good morrow, general.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: ’Tis well blown, lads.
This morning, like the spirit of a youth
That means to be of note, begins betimes.
So, so; come give me that: this way—well said.
Fare thee well, dame, what e’er becomes of me.
This is a soldier’s kiss; rebukable
And worthy shameful check it were, to stand
On more mechanic compliment. I’ll leave thee
Now like a man of steel. You that will fight,
Follow me close, I’ll bring you to’t. Adieu.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Antony, Eros, Scarus, Captains, and Soldiers.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Please you retire to your chamber?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Lead me.
He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might
Determine this great war in single fight!
Then, Antony—but now—Well, on.

scene.scenedescription: Antony learns that Enobarbus has deserted him. He sends Enobarbus’s possessions after him.
scene.stagedir: Trumpets sound. Enter Antony and Eros, Scarus meeting them.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevail’d
To make me fight at land!

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: Hadst thou done so,
The kings that have revolted, and the soldier
That has this morning left thee, would have still
Followed thy heels.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Who’s gone this morning?

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: Who?
One ever near thee. Call for Enobarbus,
He shall not hear thee, or from Caesar’s camp
Say “I am none of thine.”

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: What sayest thou?

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: Sir,
He is with Caesar.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Sir, his chests and treasure
He has not with him.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Is he gone?

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: Most certain.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Go, Eros, send his treasure after; do it,
Detain no jot, I charge thee. Write to him
(I will subscribe) gentle adieus and greetings;
Say that I wish he never find more cause
To change a master. O, my fortunes have
Corrupted honest men! Dispatch. Enobarbus!

scene.scenepersonae: (Agrippa, Caesar, Enobarbus, Dolabella, Caesar’s Third Messenger, Caesar’s First Soldier)
scene.scenedescription: Enobarbus begins to repent his faithlessness as he sees how Caesar treats other deserters, hanging them or putting them in the most dangerous spot of the battle. Receiving his treasure, he resolves to die.
scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter Agrippa, Caesar, with Enobarbus and Dolabella.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.
Our will is Antony be took alive;
Make it so known.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Caesar, I shall.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: The time of universal peace is near.
Prove this a prosp’rous day, the three-nook’d world
Shall bear the olive freely.

speech.speaker: CAES. 3. MESS.
speech.line: Antony
Is come into the field.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Go charge Agrippa
Plant those that have revolted in the vant,
That Antony may seem to spend his fury
Upon himself.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Alexas did revolt, and went to Jewry on
Affairs of Antony, there did dissuade
Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar,
And leave his master Antony; for this pains
Caesar hath hang’d him. Canidius and the rest
That fell away have entertainment, but
No honorable trust. I have done ill,
Of which I do accuse myself so sorely
That I will joy no more.

speech.speaker: CAES. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Enobarbus, Antony
Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with
His bounty overplus. The messenger
Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now
Unloading of his mules.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: I give it you.

speech.speaker: CAES. 1. SOLD.
speech.line: Mock not, Enobarbus,
I tell you true. Best you saf’d the bringer
Out of the host; I must attend mine office,
Or would have done’t myself. Your emperor
Continues still a Jove.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: I am alone the villain of the earth,
And feel I am so most. O Antony,
Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid
My better service, when my turpitude
Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart.
If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean
Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do’t, I feel.
I fight against thee? No, I will go seek
Some ditch wherein to die; the foul’st best fits
My latter part of life.

scene.scenelocation: Field of battle between the camps.
scene.scenedescription: Antony and his commanders realize that they have won a massive victory over Caesar.
scene.stagedir: Alarum. Drums and Trumpets. Enter Agrippa and others.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: Retire, we have engag’d ourselves too far.
Caesar himself has work, and our oppression
Exceeds what we expected.

scene.stagedir: Alarums. Enter Antony, and Scarus wounded.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!
Had we done so at first, we had droven them home
With clouts about their heads.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thou bleed’st apace.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: I had a wound here that was like a T,
But now ’tis made an H.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: They do retire.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: We’ll beat ’em into bench-holes. I have yet
Room for six scotches more.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves
For a fair victory.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: Let us score their backs,
And snatch ’em up, as we take hares, behind:
’Tis sport to maul a runner.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I will reward thee
Once for thy sprightly comfort, and tenfold
For thy good valor. Come thee on.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: I’ll halt after.

scene.scenedescription: Antony reports his victory to Cleopatra.
scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter Antony again, in a march, Scarus, with others.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: We have beat him to his camp. Run one before,
And let the Queen know of our gests. Tomorrow,
Before the sun shall see ’s, we’ll spill the blood
That has today escap’d. I thank you all,
For doughty-handed are you, and have fought
Not as you serv’d the cause, but as’t had been
Each man’s like mine; you have shown all Hectors.
Enter the city, clip your wives, your friends,
Tell them your feats, whilst they with joyful tears
Wash the congealment from your wounds, and kiss
The honor’d gashes whole.
Give me thy hand;
To this great fairy I’ll commend thy acts,
Make her thanks bless thee.
O thou day o’ th’ world,
Chain mine arm’d neck, leap thou, attire and all,
Through proof of harness to my heart, and there
Ride on the pants triumphing!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Lord of lords!
O infinite virtue, com’st thou smiling from
The world’s great snare uncaught?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Mine nightingale,
We have beat them to their beds. What, girl, though grey
Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha’ we
A brain that nourishes our nerves, and can
Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man,
Commend unto his lips thy favoring hand.
Kiss it, my warrior; he hath fought today
As if a god, in hate of mankind, had
Destroyed in such a shape.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I’ll give thee, friend,
An armor all of gold; it was a king’s.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: He has deserv’d it, were it carbuncled
Like holy Phoebus’ car. Give me thy hand.
Through Alexandria make a jolly march,
Bear our hack’d targets like the men that owe them.
Had our great palace the capacity
To camp this host, we all would sup together,
And drink carouses to the next day’s fate,
Which promises royal peril. Trumpeters,
With brazen din blast you the city’s ear,
Make mingle with our rattling taborines,
That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together,
Applauding our approach.

scene.scenepersonae: (Caesar’s Sentry, Caesar’s First Watchman, Caesar’s Second Watchman, Enobarbus)
scene.scenedescription: Sentries overhear Enobarbus repenting before he dies.
scene.stagedir: Enter Caesar’s Sentry and his Company. Enobarbus follows.

speech.speaker: CAES. SENT.
speech.line: If we be not reliev’d within this hour,
We must return to th’ court of guard. The night
Is shiny, and they say we shall embattle
By th’ second hour i’ th’ morn.

speech.speaker: CAES. 1. WATCH.
speech.line: This last day was
A shrewd one to ’s.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: O, bear me witness, night—

speech.speaker: CAES. 2. WATCH.
speech.line: What man is this?

speech.speaker: CAES. 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Stand close, and list him.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: Be witness to me, O thou blessed moon,
When men revolted shall upon record
Bear hateful memory: poor Enobarbus did
Before thy face repent.

speech.speaker: SENT.
speech.line: Enobarbus?

speech.speaker: CAES. 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Peace!
Hark further.

speech.speaker: ENO.
speech.line: O sovereign mistress of true melancholy,
The poisonous damp of night dispunge upon me,
That life, a very rebel to my will,
May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart
Against the flint and hardness of my fault,
Which being dried with grief will break to powder,
And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony,
Nobler than my revolt is infamous,
Forgive me in thine own particular,
But let the world rank me in register
A master-leaver and a fugitive.
O Antony! O Antony!

speech.speaker: CAES. 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Let’s speak to him.

speech.speaker: CAES. SENT.
speech.line: Let’s hear him, for the things he speaks
May concern Caesar.

speech.speaker: CAES. 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Let’s do so. But he sleeps.

speech.speaker: CAES. SENT.
speech.line: Swoonds rather, for so bad a prayer as his
Was never yet for sleep.

speech.speaker: CAES. 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Go we to him.

speech.speaker: CAES. 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Awake, sir, awake, speak to us.

speech.speaker: CAES. 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Hear you, sir?

speech.speaker: CAES. SENT.
speech.line: The hand of death hath raught him.
Hark, the drums
Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him
To th’ court of guard; he is of note. Our hour
Is fully out.

speech.speaker: CAES. 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Come on then, he may recover yet.

scene.scenelocation: The field of battle between the camps.
scene.scenedescription: Antony prepares for another battle.
scene.stagedir: Enter Antony and Scarus with their army.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Their preparation is today by sea,
We please them not by land.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: For both, my lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I would they’ld fight i’ th’ fire or i’ th’ air;
We’ld fight there too. But this it is: our foot
Upon the hills adjoining to the city
Shall stay with us—order for sea is given,
They have put forth the haven—
Where their appointment we may best discover,
And look on their endeavor.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the field of battle between the camps.
scene.scenedescription: Caesar gives his instructions for the battle.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: But being charg’d, we will be still by land,
Which as I take’t we shall, for his best force
Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales,
And hold our best advantage.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the field of battle between the camps.
scene.scenedescription: Antony witnesses his fleet yielding to the foe and realizes that he is done for. Convinced that Cleopatra has betrayed him, he swears to kill her.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Yet they are not join’d. Where yond pine does stand
I shall discover all; I’ll bring thee word
Straight how ’tis like to go.

scene.stagedir: Alarum afar off, as at a sea-fight.

speech.speaker: SCAR.
speech.line: Swallows have built
In Cleopatra’s sails their nests. The auguries
Say they know not, they cannot tell, look grimly,
And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony
Is valiant, and dejected, and by starts
His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear
Of what he has, and has not.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: All is lost!
This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me.
My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder
They cast their caps up and carouse together
Like friends long lost. Triple-turn’d whore! ’Tis thou
Hast sold me to this novice, and my heart
Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly;
For when I am reveng’d upon my charm,
I have done all. Bid them all fly, be gone.
O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more,
Fortune and Antony part here, even here
Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts
That spannell’d me at heels, to whom I gave
Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets
On blossoming Caesar; and this pine is bark’d,
That overtopp’d them all. Betray’d I am.
O this false soul of Egypt! This grave charm,
Whose eye beck’d forth my wars and call’d them home,
Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end,
Like a right gypsy, hath at fast and loose
Beguil’d me to the very heart of loss.
What, Eros, Eros!
Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Why is my lord enrag’d against his love?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving,
And blemish Caesar’s triumph. Let him take thee
And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!
Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot
Of all thy sex; most monster-like, be shown
For poor’st diminutives, for dolts, and let
Patient Octavia plough thy visage up
With her prepared nails.
’Tis well th’ art gone,
If it be well to live; but better ’twere
Thou fell’st into my fury, for one death
Might have prevented many. Eros, ho!
The shirt of Nessus is upon me; teach me,
Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage.
Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o’ th’ moon,
And with those hands, that grasp’d the heaviest club,
Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die.
To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall
Under this plot. She dies for’t. Eros, ho!

scene.scenedescription: Terrified, Cleopatra sends Mardian to Antony to falsely report that she has killed herself, while she takes refuge in her monument.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Help me, my women! O, he’s more mad
Than Telamon for his shield; the boar of Thessaly
Was never so emboss’d.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: To th’ monument!
There lock yourself, and send him word you are dead.
The soul and body rive not more in parting
Than greatness going off.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: To th’ monument!
Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself;
Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,”
And word it, prithee, piteously. Hence, Mardian,
And bring me how he takes my death. To th’ monument!

scene.scenelocation: Alexandria. Another room in Cleopatra’s palace.
scene.scenepersonae: (Antony, Eros, Mardian, Decretas, Antony’s First Guardsman, Antony’s Second Guardsman, Antony’s Third Guardsman, Diomedes)
scene.scenedescription: Antony receives the false news that Cleopatra is dead, and resolves to die himself. He begs his servant Eros to kill him, but Eros is unwilling and kills himself instead rather than witness his master’s death. Antony stabs himself, but doesn’t quite succeed in getting the job done. He is carried to Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Eros, thou yet behold’st me?

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Ay, noble lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Sometime we see a cloud that’s dragonish,
A vapor sometime like a bear or lion,
A tower’d citadel, a pendant rock,
A forked mountain, or blue promontory
With trees upon’t that nod unto the world,
And mock our eyes with air. Thou hast seen these signs,
They are black vesper’s pageants.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Ay, my lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: That which is now a horse, even with a thought
The rack dislimns, and makes it indistinct
As water is in water.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: It does, my lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is
Even such a body. Here I am Antony,
Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
I made these wars for Egypt, and the Queen,
Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine—
Which whilst it was mine had annex’d unto’t
A million more (now lost)—she, Eros, has
Pack’d cards with Caesar’s, and false-play’d my glory
Unto an enemy’s triumph.
Nay, weep not, gentle Eros, there is left us
Ourselves to end ourselves.
O, thy vild lady!
She has robb’d me of my sword.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: No, Antony,
My mistress lov’d thee, and her fortunes mingled
With thine entirely.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Hence, saucy eunuch, peace!
She hath betray’d me, and shall die the death.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Death of one person can be paid but once,
And that she has discharg’d. What thou wouldst do
Is done unto thy hand; the last she spake
Was “Antony, most noble Antony!”
Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
The name of Antony; it was divided
Between her heart and lips. She rend’red life,
Thy name so buried in her.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Dead then?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Dead.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Unarm, Eros, the long day’s task is done,
And we must sleep.
That thou depart’st hence safe
Does pay thy labor richly; go.
Off, pluck off,
The sevenfold shield of Ajax cannot keep
The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!
Heart, once be stronger than thy continent,
Crack thy frail case! Apace, Eros, apace.
No more a soldier. Bruised pieces, go,
You have been nobly borne.—From me awhile.
I will o’ertake thee, Cleopatra, and
Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now
All length is torture; since the torch is out,
Lie down and stray no farther. Now all labor
Mars what it does; yea, very force entangles
Itself with strength. Seal then, and all is done.
Eros!—I come, my queen!—Eros!—Stay for me!
Where souls do couch on flowers, we’ll hand in hand,
And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.
Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops,
And all the haunt be ours. Come, Eros, Eros!

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: What would my lord?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Since Cleopatra died
I have liv’d in such dishonor that the gods
Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword
Quarter’d the world, and o’er green Neptune’s back
With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack
The courage of a woman—less noble mind
Than she which by her death our Caesar tells,
“I am conqueror of myself.” Thou art sworn, Eros,
That when the exigent should come, which now
Is come indeed, when I should see behind me
Th’ inevitable prosecution of
Disgrace and horror, that on my command
Thou then wouldst kill me. Do’t, the time is come.
Thou strik’st not me, ’tis Caesar thou defeat’st.
Put color in thy cheek.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: The gods withhold me!
Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,
Though enemy, lost aim and could not?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Eros,
Wouldst thou be window’d in great Rome, and see
Thy master thus with pleach’d arms, bending down
His corrigible neck, his face subdu’d
To penetrative shame, whilst the wheel’d seat
Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded
His baseness that ensued?

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: I would not see’t.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Come then; for with a wound I must be cur’d.
Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn
Most useful for thy country.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: O, sir, pardon me!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: When I did make thee free, swor’st thou not then
To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once,
Or thy precedent services are all
But accidents unpurpos’d. Draw, and come.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Turn from me then that noble countenance,
Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Lo thee!

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: My sword is drawn.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Then let it do at once
The thing why thou hast drawn it.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: My dear master,
My captain, and my emperor: let me say,
Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: ’Tis said, man, and farewell.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Now, Eros.

speech.speaker: EROS.
speech.line: Why, there then.
Thus I do escape the sorrow
Of Antony’s death.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thrice-nobler than myself!
Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what
I should, and thou couldst not. My queen and Eros
Have by their brave instruction got upon me
A nobleness in record; but I will be
A bridegroom in my death, and run into’t
As to a lover’s bed. Come then; and, Eros,
Thy master dies thy scholar: to do thus
I learnt of thee. How, not dead? Not dead?
The guard, ho! O, dispatch me!

scene.stagedir: Enter Decretas and Antony’s First Guardsman.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. GUARD.
speech.line: What’s the noise?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I have done my work ill, friends. O, make an end
Of what I have begun.

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. GUARD.
speech.line: The star is fall’n.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. GUARD.
speech.line: And time is at his period.

speech.speaker: ALL. GUARDS.
speech.line: Alas, and woe!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Let him that loves me strike me dead.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. GUARD.
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: ANT. 2. GUARD.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: ANT. 3. GUARD.
speech.line: Nor any one.

speech.speaker: DEC.
speech.line: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,
Shall enter me with him.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Where’s Antony?

speech.speaker: DEC.
speech.line: There, Diomed, there.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Lives he?
Wilt thou not answer, man?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword, and give me
Sufficing strokes for death.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Most absolute lord,
My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: When did she send thee?

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Now, my lord.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Where is she?

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: Lock’d in her monument. She had a prophesying fear
Of what hath come to pass; for when she saw
(Which never shall be found) you did suspect
She had dispos’d with Caesar, and that your rage
Would not be purg’d, she sent you word she was dead;
But fearing since how it might work, hath sent
Me to proclaim the truth, and I am come,
I dread, too late.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, I prithee.

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: What ho! The Emperor’s guard! The guard, what ho!
Come, your lord calls!

scene.stagedir: Enter four or five of the Guard of Antony.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides,
’Tis the last service that I shall command you.

speech.speaker: ANT. 1. GUARD.
speech.line: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear
All your true followers out.

speech.speaker: ALL. GUARDS.
speech.line: Most heavy day!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate
To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome
Which comes to punish us, and we punish it
Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up.
I have led you oft, carry me now, good friends,
And have my thanks for all.

scene.scenelocation: Alexandria. Another room in a monument in Cleopatra’s palace.
scene.scenepersonae: (Cleopatra, Maids, Charmian, Iras, Diomed, Antony’s First Guardsman, Antony’s Second Guardsman, Antony’s Third Guardsman)
scene.scenedescription: Antony and Cleopatra exchange their last words together. He is lifted up to her in the monument and gives her some final advice. On his dying, she faints, but revives and decides to follow him.
scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra and her maids aloft, with Charmian and Iras.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Be comforted, dear madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: No, I will not.
All strange and terrible events are welcome,
But comforts we despise; our size of sorrow,
Proportion’d to our cause, must be as great
As that which makes it.
How now? Is he dead?

speech.speaker: DIO.
speech.line: His death’s upon him, but not dead.
Look out o’ th’ other side your monument,
His guard have brought him thither.

scene.stagedir: Enter below Antony, and the Guard bearing him.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O sun,
Burn the great sphere thou mov’st in! Darkling stand
The varying shore o’ th’ world! O Antony,
Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help;
Help, friends below, let’s draw him hither.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Peace!
Not Caesar’s valor hath o’erthrown Antony,
But Antony’s hath triumph’d on itself.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: So it should be, that none but Antony
Should conquer Antony, but woe ’tis so!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I am dying, Egypt, dying; only
I here importune death awhile, until
Of many thousand kisses the poor last
I lay upon thy lips.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I dare not, dear—
Dear my lord, pardon—I dare not,
Lest I be taken. Not th’ imperious show
Of the full-fortun’d Caesar ever shall
Be brooch’d with me, if knife, drugs, serpents have
Edge, sting, or operation. I am safe:
Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes
And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor
Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony—
Help me, my women—we must draw thee up.
Assist, good friends.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: O, quick, or I am gone.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Here’s sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!
Our strength is all gone into heaviness,
That makes the weight. Had I great Juno’s power,
The strong-wing’d Mercury should fetch thee up,
And set thee by Jove’s side. Yet come a little—
Wishers were ever fools—O, come, come, come,
speech.stagedir: They heave Antony aloft to Cleopatra.
speech.line: And welcome, welcome! Die when thou hast liv’d,
Quicken with kissing. Had my lips that power,
Thus would I wear them out.

speech.speaker: ALL. GUARDS.
speech.line: A heavy sight!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I am dying, Egypt, dying.
Give me some wine, and let me speak a little.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: No, let me speak, and let me rail so high,
That the false huswife Fortune break her wheel,
Provok’d by my offense.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: One word, sweet queen:
Of Caesar seek your honor, with your safety. O!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: They do not go together.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Gentle, hear me:
None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: My resolution and my hands I’ll trust,
None about Caesar.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: The miserable change now at my end
Lament nor sorrow at; but please your thoughts
In feeding them with those my former fortunes
Wherein I liv’d, the greatest prince o’ th’ world,
The noblest; and do now not basely die,
Not cowardly put off my helmet to
My countryman—a Roman by a Roman
Valiantly vanquish’d. Now my spirit is going,
I can no more.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Noblest of men, woo’t die?
Hast thou no care of me? Shall I abide
In this dull world, which in thy absence is
No better than a sty? O, see, my women:
The crown o’ th’ earth doth melt. My lord!
O, wither’d is the garland of the war,
The soldier’s pole is fall’n! Young boys and girls
Are level now with men; the odds is gone,
And there is nothing left remarkable
Beneath the visiting moon.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: O, quietness, lady!

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: She’s dead too, our sovereign.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Lady!

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: Madam!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: O madam, madam, madam!

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: Royal Egypt!
Empress!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Peace, peace, Iras!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: No more but e’en a woman, and commanded
By such poor passion as the maid that milks
And does the meanest chares. It were for me
To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods,
To tell them that this world did equal theirs
Till they had stol’n our jewel. All’s but naught:
Patience is sottish, and impatience does
Become a dog that’s mad. Then is it sin
To rush into the secret house of death
Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women?
What, what, good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian?
My noble girls! Ah, women, women! Look
Our lamp is spent, it’s out. Good sirs, take heart,
We’ll bury him; and then, what’s brave, what’s noble,
Let’s do’t after the high Roman fashion,
And make death proud to take us. Come, away,
This case of that huge spirit now is cold.
Ah, women, women! Come, we have no friend
But resolution and the briefest end.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt, those above bearing off Antony’s body.

scene.scenepersonae: (Caesar, Agrippa, Dolabella, Maecenas, Gallus, Proculeius, Decretas, Second Egyptian Servant)
scene.scenedescription: Caesar is informed of Antony’s death. Caesar sends Proculeius to Cleopatra to tell her he’ll do right by her.
scene.stagedir: Enter Caesar with his council of war: Agrippa, Dolabella, Maecenas, Gallus, Proculeius.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield;
Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks
The pauses that he makes.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Caesar, I shall.

scene.stagedir: Enter Decretas with the sword of Antony.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar’st
Appear thus to us?

speech.speaker: DEC.
speech.line: I am call’d Decretas;
Mark Antony I serv’d, who best was worthy
Best to be serv’d. Whilst he stood up and spoke,
He was my master, and I wore my life
To spend upon his haters. If thou please
To take me to thee, as I was to him
I’ll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not,
I yield thee up my life.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: What is’t thou say’st?

speech.speaker: DEC.
speech.line: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: The breaking of so great a thing should make
A greater crack. The round world
Should have shook lions into civil streets,
And citizens to their dens. The death of Antony
Is not a single doom, in the name lay
A moi’ty of the world.

speech.speaker: DEC.
speech.line: He is dead, Caesar,
Not by a public minister of justice,
Nor by a hired knife, but that self hand
Which writ his honor in the acts it did
Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it,
Splitted the heart. This is his sword,
I robb’d his wound of it; behold it stain’d
With his most noble blood.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Look you sad, friends?
The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings
To wash the eyes of kings.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: And strange it is
That nature must compel us to lament
Our most persisted deeds.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: His taints and honors
Wag’d equal with him.

speech.speaker: AGR.
speech.line: A rarer spirit never
Did steer humanity; but you gods will give us
Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touch’d.

speech.speaker: MAEC.
speech.line: When such a spacious mirror’s set before him,
He needs must see himself.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: O Antony,
I have followed thee to this; but we do launch
Diseases in our bodies. I must perforce
Have shown to thee such a declining day,
Or look on thine; we could not stall together
In the whole world. But yet let me lament,
With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts,
That thou, my brother, my competitor
In top of all design, my mate in empire,
Friend and companion in the front of war,
The arm of mine own body, and the heart
Where mine his thoughts did kindle—that our stars,
Unreconciliable, should divide
Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends—
But I will tell you at some meeter season,
The business of this man looks out of him;
We’ll hear him what he says.—Whence are you?

speech.speaker: 2. EGYPT. SERV.
speech.line: A poor Egyptian yet; the Queen my mistress,
Confin’d in all she has, her monument,
Of thy intents desires instruction,
That she preparedly may frame herself
To th’ way she’s forc’d to.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Bid her have good heart.
She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,
How honorable and how kindly we
Determine for her; for Caesar cannot live
To be ungentle.

speech.speaker: 2. EGYPT. SERV.
speech.line: So the gods preserve thee!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say
We purpose her no shame. Give her what comforts
The quality of her passion shall require,
Lest in her greatness, by some mortal stroke
She do defeat us; for her life in Rome
Would be eternal in our triumph. Go,
And with your speediest bring us what she says,
And how you find of her.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Caesar, I shall.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Gallus, go you along.
Where’s Dolabella,
To second Proculeius?

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Dolabella!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Let him alone; for I remember now
How he’s employ’d; he shall in time be ready.
Go with me to my tent, where you shall see
How hardly I was drawn into this war,
How calm and gentle I proceeded still
In all my writings. Go with me, and see
What I can show in this.

scene.scenelocation: Alexandria. Another room in a monument in Cleopatra’s palace.
scene.scenepersonae: (Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, Mardian, Proculeius, Dolabella, Caesar, Gallus, Maecenas, Seleucus, First Roman Guard, Second Roman Guard, Clown, First Roman Soldier, Second Roman Soldier)
scene.scenedescription: Cleopatra is traitorously seized by Proculeius, who has orders to keep her from killing herself. Caesar arrives to talk with Cleopatra, untruthfully telling her that he means her no harm, and she just as deceitfully convinces him that she wants to live. Dolabella confirms that Caesar’s actual intent is to show Cleopatra off as a prize of war in a triumph in Rome. Refusing to allow this to happen, Cleopatra makes the final decision to die, using some asps she has snuck in by a countryman. She dresses in her royal robes and lets the snakes bite her. Caesar’s guards come in too late to stop her. Caesar arrives to view the scene.
scene.stagedir: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Mardian.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: My desolation does begin to make
A better life. ’Tis paltry to be Caesar;
Not being Fortune, he’s but Fortune’s knave,
A minister of her will: and it is great
To do that thing that ends all other deeds,
Which shackles accidents and bolts up change,
Which sleeps, and never palates more the dung,
The beggar’s nurse and Caesar’s.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt,
And bids thee study on what fair demands
Thou mean’st to have him grant thee.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What’s thy name?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: My name is Proculeius.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Antony
Did tell me of you, bade me trust you, but
I do not greatly care to be deceiv’d,
That have no use for trusting. If your master
Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him
That majesty, to keep decorum, must
No less beg than a kingdom. If he please
To give me conquer’d Egypt for my son,
He gives me so much of mine own as I
Will kneel to him with thanks.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Be of good cheer;
Y’ are fall’n into a princely hand, fear nothing.
Make your full reference freely to my lord,
Who is so full of grace that it flows over
On all that need. Let me report to him
Your sweet dependancy, and you shall find
A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness
Where he for grace is kneel’d to.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Pray you tell him
I am his fortune’s vassal, and I send him
The greatness he has got. I hourly learn
A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly
Look him i’ th’ face.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: This I’ll report, dear lady.
Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied
Of him that caus’d it.
You see how easily she may be surpris’d.
Guard her till Caesar come.

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: Royal Queen!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: O Cleopatra! Thou art taken, Queen.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Quick, quick, good hands.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Hold, worthy lady, hold!
Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this
Reliev’d, but not betray’d.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What, of death too,
That rids our dogs of languish?

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: Cleopatra,
Do not abuse my master’s bounty by
Th’ undoing of yourself. Let the world see
His nobleness well acted, which your death
Will never let come forth.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Where art thou, death?
Come hither, come! Come, come, and take a queen
Worth many babes and beggars!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: O, temperance, lady!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Sir, I will eat no meat, I’ll not drink, sir;
If idle talk will once be necessary,
I’ll not sleep neither. This mortal house I’ll ruin,
Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I
Will not wait pinion’d at your master’s court,
Nor once be chastis’d with the sober eye
Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up,
And show me to the shouting varlotry
Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt
Be gentle grave unto me! Rather on Nilus’ mud
Lay me stark-nak’d, and let the water-flies
Blow me into abhorring! Rather make
My country’s high pyramides my gibbet,
And hang me up in chains!

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: You do extend
These thoughts of horror further than you shall
Find cause in Caesar.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Proculeius,
What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows,
And he hath sent for thee. For the Queen,
I’ll take her to my guard.

speech.speaker: PRO.
speech.line: So, Dolabella,
It shall content me best. Be gentle to her.
To Caesar I will speak what you shall please,
If you’ll employ me to him.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Say, I would die.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I cannot tell.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Assuredly you know me.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: No matter, sir, what I have heard or known.
You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams;
Is’t not your trick?

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: I understand not, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I dreamt there was an Emperor Antony.
O, such another sleep, that I might see
But such another man!

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: If it might please ye—

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: His face was as the heav’ns, and therein stuck
A sun and moon, which kept their course, and lighted
The little O, th’ earth.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Most sovereign creature—

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: His legs bestrid the ocean, his rear’d arm
Crested the world, his voice was propertied
As all the tuned spheres, and that to friends;
But when he meant to quail and shake the orb,
He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty,
There was no winter in’t; an autumn it was
That grew the more by reaping. His delights
Were dolphin-like, they show’d his back above
The element they liv’d in. In his livery
Walk’d crowns and crownets; realms and islands were
As plates dropp’d from his pocket.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Cleopatra!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Think you there was or might be such a man
As this I dreamt of?

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Gentle madam, no.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: You lie up to the hearing of the gods!
But if there be, nor ever were one such,
It’s past the size of dreaming. Nature wants stuff
To vie strange forms with fancy; yet t’ imagine
An Antony were nature’s piece ’gainst fancy,
Condemning shadows quite.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Hear me, good madam:
Your loss is as yourself, great; and you bear it
As answering to the weight. Would I might never
O’ertake pursu’d success, but I do feel,
By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites
My very heart at root.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: I thank you, sir.
Know you what Caesar means to do with me?

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Nay, pray you, sir.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Though he be honorable—

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: He’ll lead me then in triumph?

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Madam, he will, I know’t.

scene.stagedir: Enter Proculeius, Caesar, Gallus, Maecenas, and others of his Train, Seleucus following.

speech.speaker: ALL. CAES. TRAIN.
speech.line: Make way there! Caesar!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Which is the Queen of Egypt?

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: It is the Emperor, madam.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Arise, you shall not kneel.
I pray you rise, rise, Egypt.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Sir, the gods
Will have it thus, my master and my lord
I must obey.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Take to you no hard thoughts.
The record of what injuries you did us,
Though written in our flesh, we shall remember
As things but done by chance.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Sole sir o’ th’ world,
I cannot project mine own cause so well
To make it clear, but do confess I have
Been laden with like frailties which before
Have often sham’d our sex.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Cleopatra, know
We will extenuate rather than enforce.
If you apply yourself to our intents,
Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find
A benefit in this change; but if you seek
To lay on me a cruelty, by taking
Antony’s course, you shall bereave yourself
Of my good purposes, and put your children
To that destruction which I’ll guard them from
If thereon you rely. I’ll take my leave.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: And may, through all the world; ’tis yours, and we,
Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall
Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: This is the brief: of money, plate, and jewels
I am possess’d of; ’tis exactly valued,
Not petty things admitted. Where’s Seleucus?

speech.speaker: SEL.
speech.line: Here, madam.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: This is my treasurer, let him speak, my lord,
Upon his peril, that I have reserv’d
To myself nothing. Speak the truth, Seleucus.

speech.speaker: SEL.
speech.line: Madam,
I had rather seel my lips than to my peril
Speak that which is not.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: What have I kept back?

speech.speaker: SEL.
speech.line: Enough to purchase what you have made known.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra, I approve
Your wisdom in the deed.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: See, Caesar! O, behold,
How pomp is followed! Mine will now be yours,
And should we shift estates, yours would be mine.
The ingratitude of this Seleucus does
Even make me wild. O slave, of no more trust
Than love that’s hir’d! What, goest thou back? Thou shalt
Go back, I warrant thee; but I’ll catch thine eyes
Though they had wings. Slave, soulless villain, dog!
O rarely base!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Good Queen, let us entreat you.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this,
That thou, vouchsafing here to visit me,
Doing the honor of thy lordliness
To one so meek, that mine own servant should
Parcel the sum of my disgraces by
Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar,
That I some lady trifles have reserv’d,
Immoment toys, things of such dignity
As we greet modern friends withal, and say
Some nobler token I have kept apart
For Livia and Octavia, to induce
Their mediation, must I be unfolded
With one that I have bred? The gods! It smites me
Beneath the fall I have.
Prithee go hence,
Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits
Through th’ ashes of my chance. Wert thou a man,
Thou wouldst have mercy on me.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Forbear, Seleucus.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Be it known that we, the greatest, are misthought
For things that others do; and when we fall,
We answer others’ merits in our name,
Are therefore to be pitied.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Cleopatra,
Not what you have reserv’d, nor what acknowledg’d,
Put we i’ th’ roll of conquest. Still be’t yours,
Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe
Caesar’s no merchant, to make prize with you
Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheer’d,
Make not your thoughts your prisons; no, dear Queen,
For we intend so to dispose you as
Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed, and sleep.
Our care and pity is so much upon you,
That we remain your friend, and so adieu.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: My master, and my lord!

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Not so. Adieu.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Exeunt Caesar and his Train.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not
Be noble to myself. But hark thee, Charmian.

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: Finish, good lady, the bright day is done,
And we are for the dark.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Hie thee again.
I have spoke already, and it is provided;
Go put it to the haste.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Where’s the Queen?

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Behold, sir.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Dolabella!

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Madam, as thereto sworn by your command
(Which my love makes religion to obey),
I tell you this: Caesar through Syria
Intends his journey, and within three days
You with your children will he send before.
Make your best use of this. I have perform’d
Your pleasure and my promise.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Dolabella,
I shall remain your debtor.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: I your servant.
Adieu, good Queen, I must attend on Caesar.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Farewell, and thanks!
Now, Iras, what think’st thou?
Thou, an Egyptian puppet, shall be shown
In Rome as well as I. Mechanic slaves
With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers shall
Uplift us to the view. In their thick breaths,
Rank of gross diet, shall we be enclouded,
And forc’d to drink their vapor.

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: The gods forbid!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Nay, ’tis most certain, Iras. Saucy lictors
Will catch at us like strumpets, and scald rhymers
Ballad ’s out a’ tune. The quick comedians
Extemporally will stage us, and present
Our Alexandrian revels: Antony
Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see
Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness
I’ th’ posture of a whore.

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: O the good gods!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Nay, that’s certain.

speech.speaker: IRAS.
speech.line: I’ll never see’t! For I am sure mine nails
Are stronger than mine eyes.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Why, that’s the way
To fool their preparation, and to conquer
Their most absurd intents.
Now, Charmian!
Show me, my women, like a queen; go fetch
My best attires. I am again for Cydnus
To meet Mark Antony. Sirrah Iras, go.
Now, noble Charmian, we’ll dispatch indeed,
And when thou hast done this chare, I’ll give thee leave
To play till doomsday.
Bring our crown and all.
Wherefore’s this noise?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: Here is a rural fellow
That will not be denied your Highness’ presence.
He brings you figs.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Let him come in.
What poor an instrument
May do a noble deed! He brings me liberty.
My resolution’s plac’d, and I have nothing
Of woman in me; now from head to foot
I am marble-constant; now the fleeting moon
No planet is of mine.

scene.stagedir: Enter First Roman Guard and Clown with a basket.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: This is the man.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Avoid, and leave him.
Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there,
That kills and pains not?

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Truly, I have him; but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal; those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Remember’st thou any that have died on’t?

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of them no longer than yesterday, a very honest woman—but something given to lie, as a woman should not do but in the way of honesty—how she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt. Truly, she makes a very good report o’ th’ worm; but he that will believe all that they say, shall never be sav’d by half that they do. But this is most falliable, the worm’s an odd worm.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Get thee hence, farewell.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: I wish you all joy of the worm.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Farewell.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his kind.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Ay, ay, farewell.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people; for indeed, there is no goodness in the worm.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Take thou no care, it shall be heeded.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is not worth the feeding.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Will it eat me?

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman. I know that a woman is a dish for the gods, if the devil dress her not. But truly, these same whoreson devils do the gods great harm in their women; for in every ten that they make, the devils mar five.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Well, get thee gone, farewell.

speech.speaker: CLOWN.
speech.line: Yes, forsooth; I wish you joy o’ th’ worm.

scene.stagedir: Enter Iras with a robe, crown, etc.

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Give me my robe, put on my crown, I have
Immortal longings in me. Now no more
The juice of Egypt’s grape shall moist this lip.
Yare, yare, good Iras; quick. Methinks I hear
Antony call; I see him rouse himself
To praise my noble act. I hear him mock
The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men
To excuse their after wrath. Husband, I come!
Now to that name my courage prove my title!
I am fire and air; my other elements
I give to baser life. So, have you done?
Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips.
Farewell, kind Charmian, Iras, long farewell.
speech.stagedir: Kisses them. Iras falls and dies.
speech.line: Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
If thou and nature can so gently part,
The stroke of death is as a lover’s pinch,
Which hurts, and is desir’d. Dost thou lie still?
If thus thou vanishest, thou tell’st the world
It is not worth leave-taking.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say
The gods themselves do weep!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: This proves me base.
If she first meet the curled Antony,
He’ll make demand of her, and spend that kiss
Which is my heaven to have. Come, thou mortal wretch,
speech.stagedir: To an asp, which she applies to her breast.
speech.line: With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate
Of life at once untie. Poor venomous fool,
Be angry, and dispatch. O, couldst thou speak,
That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass
Unpolicied!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: O eastern star!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: Peace, peace!
Dost thou not see my baby at my breast,
That sucks the nurse asleep?

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: O, break! O, break!

speech.speaker: CLEO.
speech.line: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle—
O Antony!—Nay, I will take thee too:
speech.stagedir: Applying another asp to her arm.
speech.line: What should I stay—

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: In this vild world? So fare thee well!
Now boast thee, death, in thy possession lies
A lass unparallel’d. Downy windows, close,
And golden Phoebus never be beheld
Of eyes again so royal! Your crown’s awry,
I’ll mend it, and then play—

scene.stagedir: Enter the Roman Guards rustling in.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: Where’s the Queen?

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Speak softly, wake her not.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: Caesar hath sent—

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Too slow a messenger.
O, come apace, dispatch! I partly feel thee.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: Approach ho, all’s not well; Caesar’s beguil’d.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: There’s Dolabella sent from Caesar; call him.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: What work is here, Charmian? Is this well done?

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: It is well done, and fitting for a princess
Descended of so many royal kings.
Ah, soldier!

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: How goes it here?

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: All dead.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Caesar, thy thoughts
Touch their effects in this: thyself art coming
To see perform’d the dreaded act which thou
So sought’st to hinder.

scene.stagedir: Enter Caesar and all his Train, marching.

speech.speaker: ALL. CAES. TRAIN.
speech.line: A way there, a way for Caesar!

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: O, sir, you are too sure an augurer;
That you did fear is done.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Bravest at the last,
She levell’d at our purposes, and being royal
Took her own way. The manner of their deaths?
I do not see them bleed.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Who was last with them?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: A simple countryman, that brought her figs.
This was his basket.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Poison’d then.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: O Caesar,
This Charmian liv’d but now, she stood and spake.
I found her trimming up the diadem
On her dead mistress; tremblingly she stood,
And on the sudden dropp’d.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: O noble weakness!
If they had swallow’d poison, ’twould appear
By external swelling; but she looks like sleep,
As she would catch another Antony
In her strong toil of grace.

speech.speaker: DOL.
speech.line: Here, on her breast,
There is a vent of blood, and something blown;
The like is on her arm.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. GUARD.
speech.line: This is an aspic’s trail, and these fig leaves
Have slime upon them, such as th’ aspic leaves
Upon the caves of Nile.

speech.speaker: CAES.
speech.line: Most probable
That so she died; for her physician tells me
She hath pursu’d conclusions infinite
Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed,
And bear her women from the monument.
She shall be buried by her Antony;
No grave upon the earth shall clip in it
A pair so famous. High events as these
Strike those that make them; and their story is
No less in pity than his glory which
Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall
In solemn show attend this funeral,
And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see
High order in this great solemnity.
